"Last night, six people were talking a lot in one room, with punch to drink first! No, my friend, you are wrong; the environment really affects crime a lot. I can promise you that."

"Oh, I know it does, but tell me this: if a forty-year-old man hurts a ten-year-old child, did the environment make him do it?"

"Well, technically, it did," Porfiry said seriously. "A crime like that can be linked to the influence of the environment."

Razumihin was getting really upset. "Oh, if you want," he shouted. "I can show you that your white eyelashes could be linked to the Church of Ivan the Great being two hundred and fifty feet tall, and I can explain it clearly, step by step, and even in a liberal way! I bet I can do it!"

"Okay! Let’s hear how you plan to prove it!" 

"He is always messing around, I swear," Razumihin yelled, standing up and waving his arms. "What’s the point of talking to you? He does this on purpose; you don’t know him, Rodion! He took their side yesterday just to make them look silly. And the things he said yesterday! They were so happy! He can keep this up for weeks. Last year, he convinced us he was going to a monastery and stuck to that for two months. Not long ago, he said he was getting married and had everything ready for the wedding. He even bought new clothes. We all congratulated him. But there was no bride, nothing—just a fantasy!"
